$x_1$ mistakenly thinks/opines that $x_2$ (du'u) is true about subject $x_3$
$x_1$=$v_2$=$j_1$ finds it important to interact socially with $x_2$=$j_2$ for reason $x_3$=$v_3$ (ka); $x_1$ is extroverted
$jd_1$=$ji_1$ is tactful in making decision $jd_2$ in matter $jd_3$ (event/state) in social interaction with $ji_2$.
$s_1$ is an alkaline battery in containment $s_3$.
$z_1$ is an anvil for striking metal $d_2$=$j_2$ with instrument $d_3$.
$x1$ is a washer placed beneath $x2$
$j_1$=$s_1$ is a wire/cable of metal $j_2$=$s_2$
column3: This may be a single or multiple strand, but must be metallic.

column2: $x_{1}$ is a brassy tone with pitch $x_{2}$ with tone source $x_{3}$.
$x_1$ is an alloy including metals $x_2$
$x_1$=$z_1$ forges $x_2$=$z_2$ out of metal $x_3$=$z_1$=$j_1$
$b_1$ is a blade of the pair of shears/scissors $j_1$.
$x_1$ solders $x_2$ and $x_3$ together
$t_1$=$j_1$ is an immune-system deficiency of $j_2$.
column3: From {jinku}, {toldu'e}. t2, t3, j3, j4  based on relative uselessness (you could use tanru to get what type-of immune deficiency you're referring at).

column2: $x1$=$d1$=$m1$ is a crown of material $x2$=$d2$=$m2$
$p_1$ is a diving suit of material $p_2$
$x_1$ is a disc with a hole in the middle; $x_1$ is a flat torus.

$x_1$ is a region/room/volume of space which is shaped like a washer (or thin or flattened torus/toroid), between inner disk/sphere $x_2$ and outer disk/sphere $x_3$, defined by midplane $x_4$, and containing $x_5$.
column3: $x_1$ {canlu}. This word contrasts with "{torxesu}" in that, while neither is necessarily a material object, this is a region of space and not an idealized object per se, and that, while this region is technically three-dimensional, it is mostly considered to be flat or nearly two-dimensional (similar to "{karda}"). Therefore, it will not take up/fill all of the space between the inner and outer spheres; it is confined approximately to the plane $x_4$. $x_3$ should enclose $x_2$ (except at most one point unless the case be degenerate), but they need not be mutually concentric. $x_1$ need not be perfectly circularly toroidal; for example, it could be elliptical (in which case, $x_2$ or $x_3$ would not be perfectly spherical either). Contrast with "{bolbi'i}", which is the whole region between the spheres $x_2$ and $x_3$ when this word makes sense, but which also does not require the nesting of the said spheres. This word is a {brapagjvo}; see: "{jinrcaiba}", "{belta}". Consider just using either "{djine}" (for an object) or "{jinca'u}" (for a region of space).

column2: $d_1$=$s_1$ is a ring/belt/band/girdle around/circling/ringing $s_2$ near total containment in some dimension(s).
$n_1$ is a quantity of doughnut.
$k_1$=$j_1$ is a well in $k_2$ containing fluid $j_2$ at location $j_3$.
$d_1$ is a sickle for cutting $d_2$, with blade of material $d_3$.
column3: Defined by semicircular blade shape. Possible synonyms: {bagdakfu}, {krudakfu}.

column2: $n_1$ is a bagel.
$x_1$ is a woven ring/wreath/bracelet of material $x_2$
$x1$=$f1$ is a hen of species $x2$=$j2$
$x_1$ is a vertex of polytope $x_2$ at locus $x_3$.
$g_1$ is a diving/dive/scuba mask covering the face of $g_2$=$f_2$=$j_1$, for use in liquid $j_2$.
$x_1$=$g_1$ immerses $x_2$=$j_1$ in liquid $x_3$=$j_2$
$l_1$ (agent) bathes $l_2$=$j_1$ in liquid $j_2$=$l_4$.
$t_{1}$=$j_{1}$ is a/the horn [brass-wind/lip-reed musical instrument; default
column3: jirnytabra refers generally to the common horn (brass instrument). "..the instrument is often informally known as the French horn. However, this is technically incorrect since the instrument is not French in origin, but German. Therefore, the International Horn Society has recommended since 1971 that the instrument be simply called the horn." (wikipedia). Also natural horn (=sampu jirnytabra), vienna horn (=vin zei jirnytabra or {tabrviena}), mellophone (={tabrmelofono}), wagner tuba ({tabrvagnri}). See also {jirna} and {tabra}.

column2: $s_1$ dives [manner of controlled falling] to $s_2$ from $s_3$ into liquid $j_2$.
column3: Different styles of diving: head first (=nitfarstedu jirsu'u), "cannonball" (=boitse jirsu'u), etc. See also {zajyjirsu'u}.

column2: $x_1$=$v_1$=$c_1$ is preserved food/feed/nutriment pickled/immersed in $x_2$=$j_2$.
column3: $x_2$=$j_2$ is salt (= {silna}), vinegar (= {slami}), alcohol (= {xalka}), sugar (= {sakta}), honey (= {bicysakta}), soy sauce (= {sobysanso}), bean paste (= {furso'epesxu}), mold paste (= {mledi} {pesxu}) and so on. {jinru} {vitno} {cidja}. See also {slamystogau}.

column2: $x_1$ cleans $x_2$ of contaminant(s)/dirt $x_3$ to standard of cleanliness $x_4$.
column6: clean;clean up;make clean;make something clean;remove contaminant(s);remove dirt;to clean (tr.)

column2: $x_1$=$p_1$ is a tissue paper/toilet paper from source $x_2$=$p_2$ for cleaning $x_3$=$j_1$
$x_1$=$t_1$ is an apron of $x_2$=$j_1$=$s_1$, keeping them clean from contaminant $x_3$=$j_2$
$c_1 = x_1$ is limitless/unlimited/boundless/unbounded (one sense) in property/domain $j_3 = x_2$.
$x_1$=$k_1$ is a credit card with accumulated debt $x_2$=$d_1$ to creditor $x_3$=$d_3$, with credit limit $x_4$=$j_1$
column3: Credit cards has credit limits; for charge cards limited by a due payment date see {detseldejykarda}. Cf. {lejykarda}, {baxydinkarda}, {vamveile'ikarda}, {maksriveikarda}, {lejykardymi'i}, {banxa}, {pleji}, {jdini}.

column2: $b_1$=$j_1$ comes to the conclusion that $j_2$ [opinion] (du'u) is true about subject/issue $j_3$ on grounds $j_4$, under conditions $b_3$.
$x_1$=$f_1$=$j_1$ is unlike $x_2$=$f_2$=$j_1$ in their opinion of $x_3$=$j_3$.
$p_2$=$j_1$ is the temperament (innate personality) of $p_1$=$j_2$.
$c_1$ is an ankle of $j_2$=$c_3$
$c_1$ is a toenail of toe $c_2$=$d_1$ of body $d_3$.
$g_1$ masturbates/fucks $g_2$ with her/his feet.
$g_1$ is $g_2$ international foot/feet (length unit) in length.
$j_1$ is a sole (part of foot) of $j_2$.
$x_1$ is the Achilles tendon of $x_2$
$c_1$ is the big toe nail of body $t_3$=$j_2$.
$t_1$ is the big toe of $t_3$=$j_2$.
$t_1$ is a heel of $j_2$.
$v_1$ is a pedal with function $v_2$, fulcrum $x_3$, and lever arm $x_4$.
$x_1$ (du'u) is easy to understand to $x_2$
$x_1$ (du'u) is hard to understand to $x_2$
$x_1$=$f_2$=$j_1$ easily understands fact(s) $x_2$=$j_2$ about $x_3$=$j_3$ under conditions of ease $x_4$=$f_3$.
column3: Composed of {jimpe}, {frili}. Completely jvajvo. See also {jmifrili}.

column2: $s_1$=$j_1$ misunderstands fact/truth $j_2$ (du'u) about subject $j_3$, an error under conditions $s_3$ by standard $s_4$.
column3: The implication is that x2 is understood by x1 about x3, but that this is an incorrect understanding. See {ki'a}, {uafli}.

column2: $x_1$ perceives concrete experience $x_2$ synesthetically as $x_3$ by means $x_4$ under conditions $x_5$
column3: Synesthesia (or synaesthesia) refers to a phenomenon whereby a given sensory experience is involuntarily associated with a sensation ordinarily experienced through a different sensory pathway: for instance, the auditory experience of different sounds may trigger the visual experience of various different colors, or different kinds of visual imagery may be associated with different textures.

column2: $g_1$ (agent) causes $j_1$ to be joined to/connected to/united with $j_2$ at common locus $j_3$.
$p_1$ [ordered set] is a train/procession/caravan/string sequenced/ordered/listed by comparison/rules $p_2$ on unordered set $p_3$=$j_1$=$j_2$.
$g_1$ [person/agent] join $s_1$ together.
$x_1$ are joined at/by $x_2$.
$x_1$=$j_3$ interprets discussion/relays messages between $x_2$=$c_1$ (set) about topic/subject $x_3$=$c_2$
column3: Doesn't explicitly imply translation like {fanva}. Here $x_1$ joins the members of $x_2$ who may otherwise be unable to communicate. $x_1$ is an interpreter.

column2: $x_1$ is the union of sets $x_2$ and $x_3$.

$x_1$ is joined/connected to/with something which is joined/connected to/with something which ... which is joined/connected to/with something which is joined/connected to/with $x_2$ via intermediate things/steps $x_3$ (ce'o), with respective points/loci of (con)juncture $x_4$ (ce'o).
column3: See ".{utka}". $x_3$ and $x_4$ are ordered lists; everywhere within this description, denote the $i$th term of $x_k$, for $k$ in Set($3, 4$), as "$x_k(i)$", where $i$ is an integer and begins indexing at $1$. $x_4$ must have exactly one term more than $x_3$ (unless this is either a vacuous selbri (id est: $x_3$ is empty and at least one of $x_1$ and $x_2$ also is/are empty) or a trivial selbri (id est: $x_1 = x_2$)); thus, $x_4$ will typically be non-empty. If $x_3$ is empty but the selbri is not vacuous or trivial, then this {selbri} means "$x_1$ {jorne} $x_2 \, x_4(1)"$; else, if the selbri is neither vacuous nor trivial, then: it means "where $N$ denotes the cardinality/list-length of $x_3$: $x_1$ {jorne} $x_3(1) \, x_4(1)$ .ije $x_3(1)$ {jorne} $x_3(2) \, x_4(2)$ .ije ... .ije $x_3(n)$ {jorne} $x_3(n+1) \, x_4(n+1)$ .ije ... .ije $x_3(N-1)$ {jorne} $x_3(N) \, x_4(N)$ .ije $x_3(N)$ {jorne} $x_2 \, x_4(N+1)$". The {veljvo} of this word break the requirement that utka$_3$ be a binary predicate (because "{jorne}" is ternary). The linking which is referenced/described by this word is the same as that which is described by "{jorne}", and each one is applicable where the other is. Thus, this word might be able to be used for Internet hyperlinking, at least in a metaphorical sense.
column6: form a chain;indirectly bound to;indirectly conjoin;indirectly connected to;indirectly joined to;indirectly linked to;indirectly united

column2: $r_1$ is measured in jordanian dinar (دينارJOD) as $r_2$ (quantity), in the Algerian monetary system $r_3$.
$x_1$ has access to $x_2$ for purpose $x_3$ ; $x_1$ is able to access $x_2$ ; $x_2$ is accessible to $x_1$
$x_1$ bans/blocks $x_2$ from accessing $x_3$
$j_1$=$s_1$ is a hyperlink/URL of resource/web page $j_2$=$s_2$ for browser $s_3$.
$u_1$ is an address bar of user interface $u_2$; $u_1$ is a widget of user interface $u_2$ for entering an address.
$j_1$ plays tennis against $j_2$ in competition $j_3$ for prize/title $j_4$.
$x_1$ is a paragraph about $x_2$ including sentence(s) $x_3$.
$p_1$ is a phrase of sentence $p_2$=$j_1$ about $j_2$ in language $j_3$.
$s_1$ is a fragment of sentence $s_2$=$j_1$ about $j_2$ in language $j_3$.
$t_1$=$m_1$ is the intonation of sentence $j_1$=$m_2$ with characteristics $t_2$=$m_3$.
$j_1$=$b_1$ is the Chinese-Mandarin language, used by $b_2$ to communicate $b_3$ (si'o/du'u, not quote)
$x_1$ is a Chinese character in writing system $x_2$ (traditional/simplified/bopomofo/etc.) meaning $x_3$.
$x_{1}$ is a quantity of Citrus sinensis [fruit/tree, etc.] of species/strain $x_{2}$.
$r_1$ is measured in renminbi yuan (¥; RMB) as $r_2$ (quantity), in the Chinese monetary system $r_3$.
$j_1$=$g_1$ is China.
$sm_1$=$j_1$ is/are Chinese style soup spoon(s) (中式湯匙) [item of cutlery] for eating $sm_2$ made of material $s_3$.
column3: A type of spoon used in Chinese cuisine with a short, thick handle extending directly from a deep, flat bowl. It is used for eating soups, stews, or loose solids such as rice, and is commonly made using porcelains and ceramics.

column2: $r_1$=$j_1$ is a China rose (Rosa chinensis) of species/strain $r_2$.
$x_1$ does whatever a spider pig does.
$t1$ fears/is afraid/scared/frightened by/fearful of spiders/arachnids/crustaceans/crabs/lobsters/non-insect arthropods of species/breed $j2$.
$x_1$=$s_1$ (mass of facts) is microbiology studying microorganisms $x_2$=$j_1$ based on methodology $x_3$
$x_1$ tells/makes known to $x_2$  fact(s) $x_3$ (du'u) about subject $x_4$ by epistemology $x_5$.
$l_1$ [rules/methods] is an epistemic logic for deducing/concluding/inferring/reasoning to/about $l_2$ (du'u).
$s_1$ is an epistemology of/about ideas of knowledge $j_1$=$s_2$ based on methodology $s_3$.
$x_1$ is weightless in gravitational field $x_2$.
column3: In other words, the field is producing an imperceptible net force on the x1, due either to distance or to a cancellation effect due to a system of more than one massive body.

column2: $m_1$ (agent) weighs object $j_2$ as $m_3$ units on scale $m_4$ (si'o) in field $j_3$.
$x_1$ wonders / wants to know what sumti satisfies the predicate $x_2$
$k_1$ is a cuisine pertaining to culture/geographical region/ethos/religion $k_2$ with dishes $j_2$ cooked/prepared by recipe(s)/method(s) $j_3$ (process).
$x_1$ is a cooking apron / kitchen apron / chef's apron.
column3: A {kosta} for keeping your other clothes clean while cooking.

column2: $x_1$=$k_1$ is a kitchen, in which $x_2$=$j_1$ cooks $x_3$=$j_2$, in home/building/structure $x_4$=$k_2$ surrounded by partitions/walls/ceiling/floor $x_5$=$k_3$ (mass/jo'u).
$x_1$=$s_1$ is a cooking surface for cooking $x_2$=$j_2$, surface of object $x_3$=$s_2$.
column3: The sumti are out of order with respect to {sefta} in order to parallel {toknu}'s place structure.

column2: $t_1$ is a frying pan/wok used by cook $j_1$ for cooking/frying/sautéing $j_2$=$t_1$, made of material $t_3$
$x_1$ is a plantain (banana) of species $x_2$.
$p_1$ is a pot used by $j_1$ for cooking/boiling/steaming $j_2$=$p_2$ with recipe $j_3$; pot made of material $p_3$
$b_1$ is a dumpling made from material $x_2$ filled with material $x_3$
$j_1$=$p_1$ considers / reflects on $j_2$=$p_2$.
$c_1$ reproach/criticizes/harshly says $c_2$ (sedu'u/text/lu'e concept) to $c_3$=$j_2$ via expressive medium $c_4$
column3: See {jursa}, {cusku}. Equivalent to "lo nu ko'a cusku ko'e ko'i ko'o kei jursa ko'i".

column2: $x_1$ (living being) belongs to species/taxon $x_2$
$x_1$ cannibalizes $x_2$; $x_1$ eats $x_2$ which is of the same species as $x_1$
$x_1$ is a fellow creature of $x_2$; $x_1$ and $x_2$ belong to the same taxon $x_3$
$s_1$ is (biological) taxonomy based on methodology $s_2$.
$ja_1$=$ji_1$ is a standard by which $ja_2$=$ji_2$ is true, set by community $ja_3$
column3: This is a {lujvo} replacement for the experimental {gismu} {dardu}, and is intended to be used inside {fi'o} clauses as the modal for the ubiquitous "by standard" place which is in so many {gismu}. See also: {dardu}, {fi'o}

column2: $x1$=$g_2$ (language) has regular grammar
$l_1$ is a regular/predictable lujvo (compound predicate word) with meaning $l_2$ and arguments $l_3$ built from phrase $l_4$ and having an argument structure according to rule $j_1$.
column3: A Lojban-specific term. The approach of jvajvo is intended to at least constrain what the $x_2$, $x_3$, $x_4$... etc. of a lujvo may be, and also to draw the semantic values of those places from the semantic values of the places of the component brivla. The rationale is that the place structure of an unknown {lujvo} should not require memorization. This was previously known as ``{dikyjvo}''; a mistranslation of ``regular lujvo'', as it used the wrong sense of ``regular'' (see {dikni}).

column2: $x_1$=$m_1$ conforms to/abides by/complies with rules/customs $x_2$=$m_2$=$j_1$
$x_1$ is a regular expression matching strings $x_2$ and capturing groups $x_3$, using flags/options/extensions $x_4$.
$x_1$=$m_1$=$j_2$ is beautiful because it follows rule $x_2$=$j_1$=$m_3$ to observer $x_3$=$m_2$; $x_1$ is symmetrical (generalized sense to anything that is beautiful due to having a pattern).
column3: See {javni} {melbi}, and compare {saxseltai} which can also be translated as "symmetrical".

column2: $r_1$ is a predictable/regular affix for word/concept $r_2$, with form/properties $r_3$, in language $r_4$.
column3: Literally 'rule affix'. In Lojban, jvarafsi are the familiar four-letter (or, more precisely, four-segment) {rafsi}, which are fully predictable in form, and of which each {gismu} has only one. For example, -badn- is the jvarafsi of {badna} 'banana', and can belong to no other word. The form of the affix -badn- may be inferred from the form of the word badna, and vice versa (if the final vowel of badna is known).

column2: $c_1$=$j_1$ wages a contest $c_2$=$j_3$ on $c_3$=$j_2$ for gain $j_4$.
$k_1$=$j_1$ plays competively against opponent $j_2$ in game $k_2$=$j_3$ (event) for gain $j_4$.
$x1$=$j3$=$p1$ is a course/[competition route] to $x2$=$p2$ from $x3$=$p3$ via points $x4$=$p4$
$xi_1$ is a racehorse of breed $xi_2$ competing in race $j_3$.
$c_1$ (quoted word(s)) is a name of $c_2$ used by $c_3$ that morphologically [strict] is a Lojbanic lujvo built from predicates metaphor/tanru $l_4$
column3: The morphology is according to Lojban grammar rules; as such, the word(s) c1 must end with vowels and in fact must exactly follow the morphology of brivla (and, moreover, lujvo; else, they would not be morphologically correct lujvo). l1 is essentially c1 modulo meaning and exact syntactic operation. The other terbri of {lujvo} (namely, l2 and l3) are not useful for names.  See also: {jvosmicme} for a slight generalization, {brivlasmicme} for a greater generalization thereof.

column2: $x_1$ is a word which is a {cmevla} (morphological name-word), referring to $x_2$ and used by $x_3$, and which is also of the form of a lujvo (excepting the last rafsi) formed from veljvo $x_4$, in language $x_5$
column3: See also: {jvocme} (closely related but sort of opposite), {cmevla} (a different generalization), {jvosmicme} (a different generalization), and {jvocmevla} (which is essentially the same except slightly narrower in assumptions and terbri).

column2: $x_1$ is a cmevla meaning $x_2$ in Lojban, which looks like a lujvo but ends with a non-terminal rafsi
column3: Examples include {lojban}, {mergug}, {camgusmis}. Officially, of course, these are just {cmevla} but the rafsi are often suggestive of the meaning. See also {cmevla}, {lujvo}.

column2: $x_1$ is a lujvo-like cmevla meaning $x_2$
column3: Refers to words like {lojban}, which are built from {rafsi} like {lujvo}, but ends in a consonant and is therefore a {cmevla} rather than a {lujvo}. See {cmevo}. Syn. {jvocmevla}.

column2: $k_1$ separates affix compound $k_2$ into its constituent affixes $k_3$; $k_1$ does morphological analysis.
The lujvo $m_1$=$l_1$ (text) is an equivalent/interchangable lujvo form of lujvo $m_2$=$l_1$ (text).
column3: This refers to the fact that Lojban's lujvo can have many forms, all of which are considered to be equal in meaning automatically. See The Lojban Reference Grammar, chapter 4, section 5: https://lojban.github.io/cll/4/5/ Not to be confused with “synonymous” ({selsmudu'i}), which may apply to entirely different words. Cf. {lujvo}, {mintu}.

column2: $x_1$ is the dust at the bottom of the cereal box, thereby illustrating the principle that the definition of a lujvo need not be constrained by that of its constituent selrafsi
$x_1$ (quote) is a lujvo/compound word(s) form which conflicts with other lujvo $x_2$ (quote) according to rule $x_3$ in language $x_4$.
column3: In Lojban, this is the case when two lujvo have different meanings/definitions but are identical in veljvo except possibly for the presence of "{zei}" (or similar) and the presence of grouping markers (which may be rendered unnecessary in some veljvo constructs but not in others, such as in "LUJVO1 {zei} LUJVO2" versus "LUJVO1 {bo} LUJVO2"). See also: "{gimkamsmikezypro}".

column2: $c_1$=$s_1$ (quoted word(s)) is a name of $c_2$ used by $c_3$ that morphologically [loose] evokes/is similar to/is Lojbanic lujvo $l_1$=$s_2$ (text; may be multiple words), similar in property/quality[/amount?] $s_3$ (ka/ni)
column3: s3 will likely just be morphological structure. Strict jvocme are a subclass of jvosmicme.  The name must "look like" a (sequence of) lujvo (according to Lojban rules), but need not exactly follow the morphological requirements thereof (in particular, c1 may end with a consonant, in which case it is a {jvocmeborvla}). See also: {jvocme} (a specialization), {jvocmeborvla} (a specialization), {brivlasmicme} (a generalization); essentially synonymous with {jvocmevla}.

column2: $x_1$ is the base-tanru / base-compound-phrase of lujvo / compound-word $x_2$
column3: lo jvotau = lo {veljvo}; only the place structure differs.

column2: $x_1$=$k_1$=$t_1$=$l_4$ is the metaphor behind the compound word $x_2$=$k_2$=$l_1$.
column3: (The places: t2, t3, t4, t5 and l2, l3 are all dependent on t1 and l1, respectively, so they are all elided.) See {tanru}, {lujvo}, {krasi}.

column2: $x_1$ (number) is the lujvo score of lujvo $x_2$ (text) determined under scoring algorithm $x_3$.
column3: lujvo score is a term specific to Lojban {lujvo}. Lujvo can be assigned a "score" by some algorithm in order to compare those lujvo. One lujvo scoring algorithm is described in The Lojban Reference Grammar, chapter 4, section 12: https://lojban.github.io/cll/4/12/ See also {vamji}.

column2: $x_1$=$z_1$ assembles/builds a compound predicate word from metaphor $x_2$=$z_2$=$l_4$ with meaning $x_3$=$l_2$ and arguments $x_4$=$l_3$
$m_1$ is an axe for cutting $k_2$ with blade $m_3$=$k_1$ propelled by $m_4$.
$b_1$=$k_1$ bites through $b_2$=$k_2$ (object) on/at specific locus $b_3$ with $b_4$ to pieces $k_3$.
$d_1$ is an incisor of $d_2$.
$x1$=$k1$=$v1$ cuts off $x2$=$k3$=$v2$ from $x3$=$k2$=$v3$, leaving $x4$=$k3$=$v4$
$d_1$ is $d_2$ cupful(s).
$k_1$ is $k_2$ (quantifier, default: one) cupfuls in quantity.

$x_1$ (agent) count-measures/evaluates $x_2$=$m_2$ [quantity] as $x_3$=$k_3$=$m_3$ [number counted] items/units of/in/pertaining to set $x_4$=$k_2$, on scale $x_5$=$m_4$ (si'o; default: from 0 representing nothing/no instances of the item, and by (units of) 1 for each additional occurrence if the item is quantized) with accuracy $x_6$=$m_5$ (ideally should be exact/perfect). $x_2$ is countably measurable.
column3: The scale sets the "counting [off] by units" and most countable things are counted from "0" (meaning nothing/no instances of the item in question) with each additional occurrence of the (quantized) item being represented by an addition "1". See: {kamre}, {zilkacmre}.

column2: $p_3$ takes a photo/picture $p_1$ depicting/representing/showing $p_2$.
$p_1$ is a photograph of $p_2$ taken by photographer $p_3$ in medium $p_4$=$k_3$.
$m_1$ (photogrammetrist) measures $m_2$=$p_2$ as $m_3$ (dimensions) with accuracy $m_5$
$x_1$ is a natural number.
column3: Includes zero and all successors of zero. See also {mulna'u}, {frinyna'u}, {mrena'u}, and {lujna'u}

column2: $p_1$ is a sequence of numbers in ascending order.
$k_1$=$f_1$=$b_1$ is the Canadian French language used by $b_2$ to express/communicate $b_3$ (si'o/du'u, not quote).
$k_1$=$g_1$=$b_1$ is the Canadian English language used by $b_2$ to express/communicate $b_3$ (si'o/du'u, not quote).
$k_1$=$g_1$ is Canada
$r_1$ is measured in canadian dollar (CAD) as $r_2$ (quantity), in the Canadian monetary system $r_3$.
$x_1$  is a wild onion/Canada onion/wild garlic/meadow garlic/Canadian garlic (Allium canadense) of species/breed $x_2$.
column6: Canada onion;Canadian garlic;meadow garlic;wild garlic;wild onion

column2: $x_{1}$ is a dim/muted tone of pitch $x_{2}$ from source $x_{3}$.
$x_1$ is a voiced postalveolar sibilant fricative sound produced by $x_2$.
column6: J sound;voiced postalveolar sibilant;voiced postalveolar sibilant fricative

column2: $x_1$ (contestant) comes in $x_2$th (integer; typically positive but no more than the length/cardinality of $x_4$; lesser values represent better performance) place in contest $x_3$ against opponents $x_4$ (complete list (not mecessarily ordered) or set of all qualifying competitors); $x_1$ has rank $x_2$ in contest/conpetition/game/tournament/campaign $x_3$.
column3: $x_3$ determines the system established for how matches/tournaments are designed or selected as well as the rules which govern the conduct of participants (competitors, judges, and audience members) in each of those matches. $x_2 = 1$ iff $x_1$ is determined to be the overall champion or best competitor according to the system/standards established by $x_3$; $x_2 = n+1$ iff $x_1$ is exactly the next-best competitor after the one with rank $x_2 = n$ (id est: in a competition, it is expected or determined that the competitor with lesser rank $x_2$ will win or did win), as determined by $x_3$.

column2: $x_1$ is the IATA (International Air Transport Association) designation/result/standard/code for general subject type $x_2$ (contextless default probably: airports) applied to specific case/entity/procedure/group/hub/terminus/location $x_3$ according to rule/IATA specification/publication $x_4$ published by/according to mandating organization $x_5$ (default: IATA)
column3: x1 need not be a name-designation/code (it could be the result of any rule), although it likely will commonly be so. Possible examples of x2-filling sumti include: the code designated to name certain (international) airports, codeshared railway stations, and separate Amtrak (railway) stations, etc.. x3 is probably outlined by IATA Resolution 763, but the exact publication of the IATA Airline Coding Directory could also be specified. For an airport (generalized)/hub that has such a specification, use {te jvinjiata} or {te se jvinjiata} (using the appropriate terbri for specifying the type of hub: tebri j2); for IATA, consider using {xe jvinjiata}. See also: {jviso}, {jvinjica'o}.

column2: $x_1$ is the ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization; French: Organisation de l'aviation civile internationale, OACI) designation/result/standard/code for general subject type $x_2$ (contextless default probably: airports) applied to specific case/entity/procedure/group/hub/terminus/location $x_3$ according to rule/ICAO specification/publication $x_4$ published by/according to mandating organization $x_5$ (default: ICAO)
column3: x1 need not be a name-designation/code (it could be the result of any rule), although it likely will commonly be so. Possible examples of x2-filling sumti include: certain (international) airport code designations, air navigation procedures, etc.. For an airport (generalized)/hub that has such a specification, use {te jvinjica'o} or {te se jvinjica'o} (using the appropriate terbri for specifying the type of hub: tebri j2); for ICAO, consider using {xe jvinjica'o}. See also: {jviso}, {jvinjiata}.

column2: $x_1$ is the IEC (International Electrotechnical Commission; French: Commission électrotechnique internationale, CEI) designation/result/standard/code for topic $x_2$ applied to specific case/individual/group/electrotechnology/thing $x_3$ according to rule/IEC specification $x_4$ published by/according to mandating organization $x_5$ (default: IEC)

$x_1$ is the BIPM (French: Bureau international des poids et mesures; English: International Bureau of Weights and Measures) designation/result/standard/code for topic $x_2$ applied to specific case/individual/group/entity/idea/thing $x_3$ according to rule/BIPM specification $x_4$ published by/according to mandating organization $x_5$ (default: BIPM)
column3: The BIPM maintains: UTC, SI, the (standard/official) international prototype of the kilogram. See also: {jviso}, {jvisrcei}, {mitre}, {snidu}, {kelvo}, {grake}, {molro}, {delno}, {xampo}.

column2: $x_1$ is the IEC (International Electrotechnical Commission; French: Commission électrotechnique internationale, CEI) designation/result/standard/code for topic $x_2$ applied to specific case/individual/group/electrotechnology/thing $x_3$ according to rule/IEC specification $x_4$ published by/according to mandating organization $x_5$ (default: IEC)

$x_1$ is the IAU (International Astronomical Union; French: Union astronomique internationale, UAI) designation/result/standard/code for topic $x_2$ applied to specific case/individual/group/body/object/feature/thing $x_3$ according to rule/IAU specification/publication $x_4$ published by/according to mandating organization $x_5$ (default: IAU)

$x_1$ is the IUPAC (International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry) name/nomenclature/designation/result/standard/code for topic $x_2$ applied to specific case/individual/group/body/object/compound/feature/thing $x_3$ according to rule/IUPAC specification/publication $x_4$ published by/according to mandating organization $x_5$ (default: IUPAC)
$x_1$ performs surgery, operates on $x_2$.
$x_1$ is Kirby/a kirby [alien species that Kirby belongs to] [hoshi no kirby]
$x_1$ is a sperm whale of species/breed $x_2$
$x_1$ is a squid/cuttlefish of species $x_2$.
$x_1$ is a pupil of the eye of $x_2$
$x_1$ is black cumin (Bunium) of species/variety $x_2$
$x_1$ (ka) is the property/state of being $x_2$
$x_1$ is made of/contains/is a quantity of camphor (chemical compound)
$x_1$ is a googol [$10^{100}$ ] of $x_2$ in dimension/aspect $x_3$ (default units).
$x_1$ is a fellow man/compatriot/mate/comrade of $x_2$, being united in $x_3$ (ka)
column3: Differs from {pendo} in being impersonal, united because of x3. Differs from {kansa} in being affectionate and empathic.

column2: $x_1$ is a chameleon of species $x_2$
$x_1$ (set, group, structure, category, class, etc.) has cardinality less than or equal to aleph-null; $x_1$ is mathematically countable (including the option of being finite).
column3: Purposefully designed as a zi'evla. $x_1$ is finite or countably infinite; there exists a bijection between (the set underlying) $x_1$ and a (not necessarily proper) subset of the set of all of the natural numbers. The empty set is finite. For "uncountable"/"uncountably infinite", use "{to'e} ({zei}) kancuka'e". See also: {cimni} / {tolcimni}.

column2: $x_1$ is a candirú of species/variety $x_2$.
$x_1$ is a kangaroo of species/breed $x_2$.

$x_1$ (property with two places for ce'u) is the property according to which members of $x_2$ (ordered set with two members) are related to each other in the same way as members of $x_3$ (ordered set with two members), or in the same way as members of $x_4$ (ordered set with two members), etc. ... (infinite number of places)
column3: This is analogy; the terms in $x_2$ are related to one another in the same way as the terms in $x_i$, for any $i>1$, and that mutual relationship is that of $x_1$. The cardinality and order of the sumti filling every terbri except the first is determined by the number of {ce'u}'s in and the main selbri in abstraction of the first terbri. See also {kenmige}, {cenmige}

column2: $x_1$ (entity) cancels $x_2$ (event)
$x_1$ is a canzone
$x_1$ is a canzone sung by $x_2$
$x_1$ is a cantaloupe of species $x_2$
$x_1$ is a sea bream of species/subspecies $x_2$
$x_1$ is a real number which belongs to the interval (0, 1), or it belongs to the set $x_2$ (contextless default: empty set), exactly.
column3: This word is good for "percentage" or "fraction" (one sense). It can be used in order to construct a lujvo for "continuum" (the interval (0,1)). Generically, no further restriction is placed upon $x_1$. In particular, it need not be rational. $x_2$ need not be a subset of the reals. However, in particular, $x_2 = Set(0,1)$ allows $x_1$ to belong to exactly $[0,1]$. $x_1$ belongs to no set which is not a subset of $(0,1) \cup x_2$.

column2: $x1$ is a boson (quantum wave-particle obeying  Bose–Einstein statistics) of type $x2$ in quantum state/with properties $x3$
$x1$ is a fermion (quantum wave-particle/quanton obeying Fermi-Dirac statistics) of type $x2$ in quantum state/with properties $x3$
$x_1$ is some canvas
column3: A piece of coarse cloth, woven from hemp, useful for making sails and tents or as a surface for paintings.

column2: $x_1$ is a complex number with real part $x_2$ and imaginary part $x_3$
$x_1$ is a carrot of species/variety/cultivar $x_2$
$x_1$ is a chili/bell pepper (Capsicum) of species/variety $x_2$.
$x_1$ and $x_2$ are elements of the same partially-ordered set $x_3$ (see notes) such that $x_1$ and $x_2$ cannot be meaningfully compared via said relation/in said property.
column3: Neither is more nor less than the other because those relations/concepts simply do not make sense for the given pair. $x_3$ accepts sumti of either of two types/structures: (1) a partially-ordered set in which both the underlying set and the order relation on it are specified explicitly (see: "{cmacistura}"); (2) a simple "ka" construct indicating a property or characteristic which roughly functions as the basis of an assumed partial-order relation on an unspecified or vague partially-ordered set, in a fashion which is grammatically approximately analogous to "{zmadu}"'s structure.

column2: $x_1$ [mass of properties describing skills, technological advances] is a civilization of $x_2$ (mass of persons) manifesting Type $x_3$ (number) on the Kardashev scale of technological advancement according to standard/particular scale/definition $x_4$.
column3: A Type I civilization can store all of the energy from $solri_1$ of its $kardacevo_2$. A Type II can harness the total energy of such $solri_1$. A Type III civilization can control energy on the scale of its entire host galaxy. See also {kulnu}, {tarso'imei}.

column2: $x_1$ is a cardomom (Elettaria cardamomum) of variety $x_2$
$x_1$ is hibiscus of species/variety $x_2$.
$k_1$ is a wolverine of variety $k_2$.
$x_1$ is a crab (type of aquatic crustacean) of type $x_2$
column3: Less taxonomically specific than {braxiiura}; generally refers to any aquatic decapod with a broad shell and pincers, including those aren't classed as infraorder Brachyura, e.g. hermit crabs, king crabs, and porcelain crabs. See {cakyjukni}.

column2: $x_1$ is a Philippine carioca dessert, bamboo-skewered caramel-coated deep fried glutinous rice balls, of variety/type $x_2$
$x1$ (number) is an absolute Fermat pseudoprime (Carmichael-Korselt number) in structure $x2$
column6: absolute Fermat pseudoprime;Carmichael number;Korselt Fermat pseudoprime

column2: $x_1$ is of carmine color
column3: Carmine color is the color of blood or cherries or tomatoes or rubies

column2: $x_1$ represents/pertains to Canaanite culture in property/aspect $x_2$
$x_1$ is a carnaúba palm, carnaubeira palm (Copernicia prunifera) of variety $x_2$
$x_1$ celebrates $x_2$ with the carnival party $x_3$ (property of $x_1$); $x_3$ is a carnival devoted to $x_2$
$x_1$ is a carnivoran (animal belonging to the Carnivora order)
$x_1$ is a caprine/a member of subfamily Caprinae, of species/breed $x_2$
$x_1$ is safflower of species/variety $x_2$.
$x_1$ reflects Punic/Carthaginian culture/language/society/nation/identity in aspect $x_2$
$x_1$ is/contains cartilage, performing function $x_2$ in body of $x_3$.
column3: Definition modeled after {bongu}. Synonym: {bogykicmai}. See also {bogykicmaifi'e} 'cartilaginous fish'.

column2: $x_1$ is Georgian (Caucasus) in aspect $x_2$.
$x_1$ is a cartoon about $x_2$
$x_1$ is a caravan consisting of $x_2$ traveling across/through $x_3$

$x_1$ (astronomical object or its part) experiences hitting its magnetosphere by a coromal mass ejection from $x_2$ (default: the only star $x_1$ is gravitationally bound to); $x_1$ experiences a Carrington event, solar storm
$x_1$ is a voiceless velar stop sound produced by $x_2$.
column3: Derived from and synonymous with {ky zei sance}. The odd morphological form serves to place the most salient consonant in the stressed syllable.
column6: K sound;voiceless velar plosive;voiceless velar stop;voiceless velar stop sound

column2: $x_1$ is a katakana (Japanese syllabary) of sound $x_2$.
$x_{1}$ reflects Catalan culture/nationality/language in aspect $x_{2}$.
$x_1$ is a cathode/negative electrode.
what satisfies property $x_1$ conditions what satisfies property $x_2$; what satisfies $x_2$ depends on what satisfies $x_1$

$x_1$ (collection, body, set, mass, tuple, n-some, etc.) is $x_2$ (li; default: 1) indivisible/atomic/elementary/basic discrete entities (or particles) of type $x_3$ in composition/content, by standard $x_4$; the count of instances of $x_3$ in $x_1$ is $x_2$ by standard $x_4$.
column3: Not an SI standard unit; dimensionality is 1 or, arguably, the same as the mole ("{molro}"); usually optional in practice. To be used for unit composition (such as count per unit time (see: )). $x_3$ values which are mutually distinct and not mutually heirarchically related/comparable produce orthogonality; for example: hydrogen atoms are counted separately from carbon atoms, but neither one is independent of the count of hydrocarbon compounds, in a given sample. Whether 'multiple' instances of mutually identical entities are each counted separately is defined by $x_4$ (where "multiple" here is not intended to bias interpretation or to be tautological). For the purposes of this word, the $x_3$-composition of $x_1$ should not be treated as a continuum. Actual/physical indivisibility need not be required; only conceptual and relevant indivisibility or basicness is required, and may be further explained or restricted via $x_4$. See also: "{kancu}", "{mei}", "{fei'u}".
column6: natural unit of counting discrete elementary entities

column2: $x_1$ is a salamander of family/genus/species $x_2$.
$k_1$ is a lepton [elementary particle] with flavour $k_2$.
$x_1$ is a cowboy
$x_1$ is a fidget spinner.
$x_1$ plays croquet against $x_2$ in competition $x_3$ for prize/title $x_4$.
$x_1$ is a slinky (toy).
$x_1$ reflects Manx culture in aspect $x_2$
$x_{1}$ is $x_{2}$ degrees Fahrenheit in temperature by standard $x_{3}$.
$x_1$ is a black hole/singularity with radius of event horizon $x_2$
column3: This is a word based on the cultural idea of a black hole, and so contains places of cultural importance, rather than the physical characteristics that define a black hole. It is a shortening of {kensa} {jipno} {se} {farlu} into a {jbofuvi}. See {gramykemjipselfa'u}.

column2: $x_1$ is to $x_2$ as $x_3$ is to $x_4$ as $x_5$ is to $x_6$ ...
column3: Takes an even number of arguments (is 2n-ary). Also means: x1 is an x2 type of x3. More widely known as a kenning; x1 : x2 :: x3 : x4 :: x5 : x6... One can use sequences ({ce'o}) as x2, x4, x6 if more than 2 things form a row.

column2: $x_1$ is an anthropomorphic animal of type/species $x_2$
$x_1$ is a centaur/hippocentaur of type/mythology $x_2$
$x_1$ is a kerbal.
column3: Kerbals are the alien species starred in the celebrated space flight simulator video game Kerbal Space Program. See also {kesli'uci'e} {jakne} {kesyvinji} {spoja} {bebna}

column2: $x_1$ (quantity) is a hair cleaning/care/maintenance/styling substance/product for purpose $x_2$ of composition $x_3$; $x_1$ is a quantity of hair product
column3: This word is something of an {u'ivla}. Not restricted to only shampoo (hair cleaning product); can include (but is not limited to): shampoo, conditioner, hair mousse/gel, hair replenisher/grower (for baldness), hair coloring dye, hair styling spray, and even shaving cream/foam; however, it should be a tool/substance applied to hair semi-permanently, rather than applied to it only initially in order to modify it for later (such as a crimper, curler, etc.)—in other words, kerfrcampu remains with the hair or is scrubbed in and then washed out in order to function. Hair need not be human, of the top of the head, or even "real"/biological/belonging to the individual in question—these characteristics may be specified by $x_2$. See also {krevelylu'i}; {campu} for gismu version of same word.
column6: hair conditioner;hair dye;hair gel;hair mousse;hair product;hair spray;hair styling substance;shampoo

column2: $x_1$ is Cornish in aspect $x_2$
$x_1$ (set) is the set of all points/input values in the domain of function $x_2$ such that that function ($x_2$) maps them to 0.
column3: $x_1$ is a subset of the domain set of $x_2$.

column2: $x_1$ is a kernel/nucleus/'nut' of $x_2$; $x_1$ is central
$x_1$ has a body mass index of $x_2$ by standard $x_3$.
$x_1$ is a pterosaur of subtaxon/type/genus/species/variety/breed $x_2$
Cuyahoga county, Ohio
column3: Not the name for the Native American people/nation/ethnicity/tribe. The "o" is stressed and may be either the open-mid or the close-mid back rounded vowel; both pronunciations are used by locals.

column2: kami, god, deity, divinity, spirit
$x_1$ is Capricornus [astronomical constellation]/Capricorn [astrological sign].
column3: From goat (={kanba}). Capricornus is Latin for "horned male goat" or "goat horn". Anyway, both male and female of the genus Capra have horns.

column2: Katarzyna
Canada
Keresth
abstractor: $x_1$ ($x_2$, ...) are such that they satisfy [bridi], binding to the open {ce'u} slots.
imaginary i (non-comma)
column3: This is literally a unit, a pure number that is treated as a scalar; it is what happens when considering C to be a field over C - ordered pairs/tuples for coordinates no longer make much sense. Thus, this number operates exactly as one might think i would/should operate: as a single number, without components. In certain bases, it can be used a pure digit (which simplifies some potential numeric strings, compared to the usage of {ka'o} therein). See also: {ka'o} (and its commentary on Jbovlaste for the justification for this word), {fai'u}.

column2: imaginary i, comma - spherical coordinates: first coordinate gives magnitude (complex modulus/radius) of the number, the second number gives the angle from the positive real axis measured counterclockwise toward the 'positive' imaginary axis (default: in the primary branch/Arg) as measured in some units (which that number should contain; the contextless default will suppose radians); the angle is not normalized.
column3: The number (r, x) = r*e^(i x); this would be denoted by "ry ka'o'ei xy". The angle x is (by default) measured in radians and is not normalized (contains no hidden/inherent multiples of pi); it will canonically be between 0 and tau radians (inclusive on only one side; "tau" here means "{tau'u}"), but it need not be so restricted; x will almost certainly be real. r is necessarily nonnegative and real. r = 0 implies that (r,x) = 0 (as a complex number - id est: complex zero); r being infinite implies that (r,x) is complex infinity (on the Riemann sphere, for example); in either of these situations, x will default to x = 0 if possible - otherwise, to the least value allowed by its domain which is congruent to 0 modulo tau radians. See also: {te'o}, {ka'o}.

column2: $x_1$ (ka) is obtained from $x_2$ (ka) by uncurrying the first N places
column3: lo ka ko'a ce'o ko'e ce'ai broda (see wiki 'Abstraction Pattern Syntax') is equivalent to "lo reka'oi co ka ce'u ce'u broda"

column2: convert bridi into n-ary property claim: $x_n$ is such that it fills the n-th occurrence of ce'u in [bridi].
column3: Similar to {poi'i} but using {ce'u} instead of {ke'a} as the binding variable, thus allowing for plural properties. In particular, allows for an alternative way of defining brivla. E.g. {cabna} = "ka'oi'i ce'u fasnu ca ce'u kei". See also {ka}, {poi'i}, {ce'u}.

column2: pro-sumti: strong-memory something1/eidetic da/elephant thing1 (logically quantified existential, arbitrarily-long-scope pro-sumti)
column3: The meaning is the same as {da} and it functions the same way except that any assignment/qualification placed upon it (except for quantification) is semantically retained throughout a discourse until {da'o} is uttered; it acts as though the scope (except for quantification that occurs outside of a POI-clause) of all previous usages are arbitrarily long, terminated only by {da'o} or the end of the discourse. User beware: usage is tricky. See also: {kau'e}, {kau'i}, {da'au}, {da}.

column2: Microdigit-spanning endianness binary-toggle.
column3: Switches the endianness of the microdigits in all subsequent numeric strings (during their interpretation phase) from big-endian to little-endian or vice-versa; macrodigit endianness is unaffected; it does span across  macrodigits (into their microdigits), until used again or terminated by the end of scope of {li}, etc. (see below). So, for example, in the context of specifying a month of the year and a day of the month (in macrodigit big-endian format: MM-DD), exactly "kau'ai pa re pi'e pa no" is in little-endian mode for exactly the microdigits and means only the first day of the twenty-first month, if it existed, (and not the twelfth day of the tenth month, the tenth day of the twelfth month, the twenty-first day of the first month, or anything else); meanwhile, exactly "kau'ai kau'ai pa re pi'e pa no" is big-endian in its microdigits and means only the tenth day of the twelfth month (and not the twenty-first day of the first month, the twelfth day of the tenth month, the first day of the twenty-first month (if it existed), or anything else). Without prior specification or context, Lojban assumes a big-endian setting (although such language is never explicitly used in the CLL), except for certain brivla (such as {detri}, currently); in such a case or in any case whatsoever other than having previously and still-actively and explicitly specified the little-endian interpretation, including bi-endian or middle-endian etc./vel sim. cases, the first active and explicit usage of this word (called the "original usage" here) switches the interpretation to little-endian; thereafter, each usage will toggle between big-endian (all odd-numbered subsequent occurrences) and then back to little-endian (all even-numbered subsequent occurrences), where the original usage (which switched away from contextless default or non-little-endian interpretation) is counted as the zeroth usage. This function is an involution (at least after the original usage). It terminates with the closing of the scope of {li}, the usage of a brivla or gadri or {du} (or similar) or {boi}, or the overarching specification for the text (iff used therein); it does span across (not terminate with) VUhU and the like. For now, it really should not be used twice within the same numeric string/macrodigit. Notice that exactly "kau'ai pa re ci" means "three hundred twenty-one" because there is only one macrodigit (so, its remaining big-endian, assuming contextless default, is inconsequential), but its microdigits have become little-endian. See also: {kau'au}.

column2: Macrodigit-spanning endianness binary-toggle.
column3: Switches the endianness of the macrodigits in all subsequent numeric strings (during their interpretation phase) from big-endian to little-endian or vice-versa; the internal structure (microdigit interpretation) of each macrodigit is not affected. So, for example, in the context of specifying a month of the year and a day of the month, exactly "kau'au pa re pi'e pa no" is in little-endian mode for exactly its macrodigits and means only the twelfth day of the tenth month (and not the twenty-first day of the first month, the tenth day of the twelfth month, the first day of the twenty-first month (if it existed), or anything else); meanwhile, exactly "kau'au kau'au pa re pi'e pa no" is big-endian for exactly its macrodigits and means only the tenth day of the twelfth month (and not the twenty-first day of the first month, the twelfth day of the tenth month, the first day of the twenty-first month (if it existed), or anything else). Without prior specification or context, Lojban assumes a big-endian setting (although such language is never explicitly used in the CLL), except for certain brivla (such as {detri}, currently); in such a case or in any case whatsoever other than having previously and still-actively and explicitly specified the little-endian interpretation, including bi-endian or middle-endian etc./vel sim. cases, the first active and explicit usage of this word (called the "original usage" here) switches the interpretation to little-endian; thereafter, each usage will toggle between big-endian (all odd-numbered subsequent occurrences) and then back to little-endian (all even-numbered subsequent occurrences), where the original usage (which switched away from contextless default or non-little-endian interpretation) is counted as the zeroth usage. This function is an involution (at least after the original usage). It terminates as {kau'ai} does: with the closing of the scope of {li}, the usage of a brivla or gadri or {du} (or the like) or {boi}, or the overarching specification for the text (iff used therein); it does span over (not terminate with) VUhU. For now, it really should not be used within the same numeric string. Notice that exactly "kau'au pa re ci" still means "one hundred twenty-three" because there is only one macrodigit (so, its now being little-endian is inconsequential) and its microdigits are still big-endian, assuming contextless default. See also: {kau'ai}.

column2: pro-sumti: strong-memory something2/eidetic de/elephant thing2 (logically quantified existential, arbitrarily-long-scope pro-sumti)
column3: The meaning is the same as {de} and it functions the same way except that any assignment/qualification placed upon it (except for quantification) is semantically retained throughout a discourse until {da'o} is uttered; it acts as though the scope (except for quantification that occurs outside of a POI-clause) of all previous usages are arbitrarily long, terminated only by {da'o} or the end of the discourse. User beware: usage is tricky. See also: {kau'a}, {kau'i}, {da'au}, {de}.

column2: pro-sumti: strong-memory something3/eidetic di/elephant thing3 (logically quantified existential, arbitrarily-long-scope pro-sumti)
column3: The meaning is the same as {di} and it functions the same way except that any assignment/qualification placed upon it (except for quantification) is semantically retained throughout a discourse until {da'o} is uttered; it acts as though the scope (except for quantification that occurs outside of a POI-clause) of all previous usages are arbitrarily long, terminated only by {da'o} or the end of the discourse. User beware: usage is tricky. See also: {kau'a}, {kau'e}, {da'au}, {di}.

column2: generic algebra unit $e_n$
column3: The structure/space in which it is being considered should be specified.  Subscripts are expected. Used for octonions, sedenions, etc. Can also be used for R, C, or H. Works like {ka'o} (as a comma) and is isomorphic to it. See also: {ka'o}, {kai'o}, {kei'o}, {koi'o}.

column2: Predicate to variable-binding binary quantifier. The first slot of the predicate must be a property.
column3: Terminator: {te'u}. Semantically equivalent to {kai'i} but behaving syntactically as a quantifier, and therefore able to bind {da}, for example. If a kau'u-phrase is followed by a selbri or a poi-clause, the referents of the x1 or ke'a slot of those will be passed collectively to the x2 of the kau'u-predicate. A kau'u-phrase followed by a sumti other than a bindable variable ({da}…) will treat this latter as if it was a selbri «me [the sumti] me'u». Usage examples: «kau'u roldza da viska da» = «roldza fa lo ka ce'u viska ri» = «ro da viska da»; «kau'u kampu lo mlatu cu se tuple vo da» = «kampu lo mlatu fa lo ka ce'u se tuple vo da» = «ro lo mlatu cu se tuple vo da». See also {kai'i}.

column2: Toggles to no grouping
column3: rafsi -ked- The grouping of gismu/rafsi is left ambiguous. So with a statement like: ke'ai melbi cmalu nixli ckule   or   kedmlecmaxlicu'e it is unclear whether this is referring to a (((pretty little)girls)school), (pretty(little(girls(school))), etc. Overridden by ke'ei or ke'ei'a. (Applies only to next selbri.)

column2: relative clause prenex: assigns a variable to the object of the relative clause
column3: Works like {ce'ai}, but binds to {ke'a} rather than {ce'u}. lo broda poi ko'a ke'au brode ko'a = lo broda poi ke'a goi ko'a zo'u brode ko'a

column2: Attaches all of the following words to the next explicitly mentioned sumti as seltau of that sumti or selbri which is explicitly marked with "cu" (under left-grouping by default).
column3: Terminates with the explicit introduction of a sumti or "{cu}", or the end of the text, only; these markings must be explicit. It applies to that sumti or selbri (whichever comes first). Can be used in order to modify words like "{mi}" adjectivally, but might be able to even apply large structures like whole brivla as seltau to sumti if used properly.
column6: make following text into seltau of next sumti or marked selbri

column2: terminates a JUhAU expression
column3: Closes the right-hand (sumti-filling) scope of words belonging to selma'o JUhAU.

column2: Toggles to right grouping of tanru/lujvo.
column3: rafsi -keb- "ke'ei'a" toggles back to left grouping. (Applies only to next selbri.)

column2: Toggles to left grouping of tanru.
column3: rafsi -kex- Toggles back to left grouping after ke'ei toggles right grouping or ke'ai toggles to no grouping.

column2: Locks tanru modification order reversal (does not affect lujvo). {ke'e'unai} restores regular order
column3: Makes all tanru in the following text "selskiski"/"military-style": i.e. {tertau} come *before* {seltau}. This essentially puts {ke'oi} before every tanru. // This is an experimental cmavo in the truest sense of the word, used to test out "what if" Lojban chose "noun-adjective"  order, which does have several advantages (chief of them being that the selbri-unit that describes the subject is uttered first), despite being unusual for English speakers.

column2: mekso style converter: elementwise application of operator
column3: Prefixed to an operator/function that operates on numbers, thereby transforming it into a set operator (thus its arguments must be sets where before they were numbers), as defined in a given structure; the result is a function of the same arity. Produces the set of all numbers that are given by some ordered tuple of elements (the nth term of which belongs to the nth set specified, for all n) with the operator acting on them/the tuple (per the rules of that operator). The set produced may include empty terms and/or infinity. Let "@" represent the operator and "$x_i$" represent a set for all i; then $x_1$ kei'ai @ $x_2$ boi $x_3$ boi $x_4$ boi $\dots$ = Set(@$(t_1, t_2, t_3, t_4, \dots)$: $t_i$ in $x_i$ for all i); the ordered Cartesian product of the operands of 'kei'ai @' must be a subset of the domain set of '@'. If f is unitary and we convert it to a set operator 'kei'ai f' = F, then for any good set A, $F(A) = \operatorname{img}_f (A)$, which is the image of A under the function/map f.  See also {kei'au} for a similar but different word.
column6: difference set;image under f;set of results of operator;sum set

column2: mekso operator: finite result set derived from/on set A with/due to operator/function B under ordering of application C
column3: Equivalent to: lo'i li zy du ca'e li pe'o se'au mau'au B zai'ai vei ma'o xy boi ny ve'o boi tau sy boi C ku poi ke'a cmaci xanri zi'e poi ke'a mleca li ci'i zo'u tau sy klesi A. Acts on an operator/function (B) and produces all finite results of that operator being used on any allowable number of elements of the set A without repetition within any given application; the results cannot be used as operands unless they are in A, but they are still in the result set. In order to overcome this limitation, iteration can be used (else, this definition may need to be modified). The result must be defined (and finite, obviously). Application of the operator on nothing (the elements of the empty set) is generically allowed and follows convention (for example, an empty sum may evaluate to 0). Differs from {kei'ai}. Use {mau'au} and {zai'ai} for quoting B. C will be specified explicitly (possibly elsewhere) and/or via {zoi'ai}.
column6: finite result set;finite sum set;finite union set

column2: digit/number: hex digit E (decimal 14) [fourteen].
column3: Used as an alternative to {rei}/{xei} due to unique consonant. Useful in crowded situations. Experimental rafsi: -kim-

column2: non-logical connective/mekso operator - of arity only 1 xor 2: set (absolute) complement, or set exclusion (relative complement). Unary: $X_{2} ^{C}$; binary: ${X_1}\setminus{X_2}$.
column3: Each input must be a set or similar. The definition of the binary case expands to "the set of exactly those elements which are in $X_1$ but not in $X_2$". This word and operator has ordered input: '$X_1$ kei'i $X_2$' is not generally equivalent to '$X_2$ kei'i $X_1$'; in other words, the operator is not commutative. If unary (meaning that $X_1$ is not explicitly specified in a hypothetical expression "${X_1}\setminus{X_2}$"), then $X_1$ is taken to be some universal set $O$ in/of the discourse (of which all other mentioned or relevantly formable sets are subsets, at the least); in this latter case, the word operates as the set (absolute) complement of the explicitly mentioned set here designated as $X_2$ for clarity (id est: the output is $O\setminus{X_2}={X_2}^{C}$, where "$^{C}$" denotes the set absolute complement; in other words, it is the set of all elements which may be under consideration such that they are not elements of the explicitly specified set). When binary with both $X_1$ and $X_2$ explicitly specified, this word/operator is the set relative complement. This word is somewhat analogous to, depending on its arity, logical 'NOT' or 'AND NOT' (just as set intersection is analogous to logical 'AND', set union is analogous to logical '(AND/)OR'  and set symmetric difference is analogous to 'XOR'). The preferred description/name in English is "set (theoretic) exclusion". See also: "{kleivmu}". For reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complement_(set_theory) .
column6: \;absolute complement;C;exclusion;relative complement;set complement;set difference;set exclusion;set minus;set subtraction

column2: quaternion j
column3: Works like {ka'o} (as a comma) and is isomorphic to it. See also: {ka'o}, {kai'o}, {koi'o}, {kau'o}.

column2: vocative: please repeat in simpler words.
reverses modification order of contained tanru (does not affect lujvo).
column3: Marks a "selskiski"/"military-style"/"noun-adjective" tanru, i.e. {tertau} come *before* {seltau}. This differs from {co} in that it does not affect the place structure of the sumti to the right; i.e. in {mi ke'oi broda brode do} (= {mi brode broda do}), both {mi} and {do} are arguments of {broda}. Default grouping is still left: {lo ke'oi ckule nixli cmalu melbi} resolves to {lo ke'oi (((ckule nixli) cmalu) melbi)}, which is equivalent to {lo melbi ke cmalu ke nixli ckule}. {co} does not (re-)reverse the order of tanru-modification; it only changes place structure. See {ke'e'u}.

column2: vocative: please repeat more slowly / more clearly enunciated.
vocative: please repeat in a language I understand better.
accepts number (n) after: repeat last sumti up to n times
column3: lo pa plise (ku) ke'u'i ci = "lo pa plise (ku) lo pa plise (ku) lo pa plise (ku)". Mostly for mathematical brivla, e.g. {konkatena}, {lairsume}, {sumji} (proposed to accept arbitrary number of places).

column2: discursive: \n{ke'u } - repeating\n{ke'u nai} - continuing.
$x_{1}$ is a cavity/hole/hollow/cavern in $x_{2}$; $x_{1}$ is concave within $x_{2}$; $x_{2}$ is hollow at locus $x_{1}$.
column3: Also pit, depression, concavity; hollow (= {selke'a}).  See also {fenra}, {kunti}, {canlu}, {canko}, {galxe}, {tubnu}.

column2: $x_{1}$ cushions $x_{2}$ with material $x_{3}$; $x_{1}$ is a cushion/pillow/pad [for $x_{2}$] of padding material $x_{3}$.
$x_{1}$ is a quantity of/contains/is made of oxygen (O); [metaphor: supporting life/combustion].
$x_{1}$ is a thousand [1000; $10^3$] of $x_{2}$ in dimension/aspect $x_{3}$ (default is units).
tense/modal: set/use tense default; establishes new open scope space/time/modal reference base.
attitudinal question: confusion about something said.
vocative: \n{ki'e} - thanks\n{ki'enai} - no thanks to you.
{ckini} modal, 1st place (related to)               relatively; as a relation of ...
$x_1$ pertains to the internet/cyberspace in aspect $x_2$.
column3: Proposed by xorxes. Short rafsi -kib-. Cf. {mujysamseltcana}.

column2: $x_1$ is $x_2$ (default 1) kilograms [SI base unit] in mass by standard $x_3$.
$x_1$ is a binary relationship which is symmetric (under exchange of arguments/terms) in space/under conditions/on set $x_2$.
column3: Denote this binary relation $x_1$ between elements y, z (in that order) by "y R z" (in that order); then, for any elements a, b in the set of consideration (possibly $x_2$), if a R b, then b R a. See also: {kinra}, {takni}.

column2: $x_1$ repeats  $x_2$ (sedu'u/text) to audience $x_3$ via expressive medium $x_4$ for the $x_5$th time.
$x_1$ is a reprise / repeated musical passage produced by $x_2$ (event)
$d_1$=$k_1$ is a dungeon excavated in or beneath $k_2$ for purpose $d_2$
$p_1$=$k_1$ is a tunnel through obstacle $k_2$, that stretches from $p_2$ to $p_3$ and goes through points $p_4$ (set)
column3: {kevna} {pluta} -- Discussed on the IRC on March 31st, 2014, around 21:00 GMT

column2: $ci_1$=$cu_1$ is a woodpecker/wryneck/piculet/sapsucker of species $ci_2$
$k_1$=$xe_1$=$j_1$ is a cleft/dimple chin of $xe_2$.
$k_1$=$z_1$ is a cave for housing $x_2$=$z_2$, located in $x_3$=$k_2$.
$z_1$=$k_1$ applauds/acclaims/praises loudly action $z_2$ (object/event) with sound $k_2$.
$c_1$=$k_1$ shouts/cries out $c_2$=$k_2$ (sedu'u/text/lu'e concept) to audience $c_3$ via expressive medium $c_4$
$d_1$ uploads $d_2$ to $d_3$=$k_1$.
$x_1$ sends spam (e-)mail $x_2$ to recipient [address] $x_3$ from mailbox address $x_4$ by network/system $x_5$
$c_1$ is a web browser for retrieving/presenting/traversing information $k_1$.
$c_1$ downloads $c_2$ from $c_3$=$k_1$.
$x_1$ is an Internet avatar/representation of user $x_2$ on website/function $x_3$
$x_1$=$p_1$ is a profile picture belonging to $x_2$=$p_2$=$kr_2$ made by $x_3$=$p_3$ on website $x_4$.
column3: Created because {kibyka'ixra} could probably refer to things that are not pictures too, e.g. a 3D video game skin.

column2: $ki_1$=$ka_1$ is an internet-journal/web-article/blog (web-log) with content $ka_2$ published by $ka_3$ for audience $ka_4$
$p_1$ is a web page of site $p_2$=$k_1$.
$c_1$ is/pertains to cyberpunk genre (as a work of culture: literature/cinema/gaming/etc) having plot/theme/subject matter $c_2$ and was created by $c_3$
column3: From {kibro} {pindi} {cfika}, "cyber-poor fiction." The longer tanru "cyber rebel genre" produced an intolerably-long lujvo (rebel and genre themselves both being lujvo).

column2: $x_1$=$k_1$=$s_1$ is a server on the Internet for a client $x_2$=$k_1$=$s_2$ of service $x_3$=$s_3$.
column3: -kib- is a short rafsi of experimental gismu {kibro}. See ${samseltcana}_2$ for nodes of a network, {kibro} {selfu}, {kibdu'a}, {kibycpa}, {kibyca'o}

column2: $x_1$ expresses/says $x_2$ (sedu'u/text) over the internet for audience $x_3$, via online medium $x_4$.
$s_1$ is a Internet forum for $c_1$ to discuss/talk about topic/subject $c_2$.
$x_1$ is a website, containing $x_2$
$x_1$ is located at website / Internet resource $x_2$
column3: See {kibystu}, {kibro}, {ki'oi}. $x_2$ need not be a website, but may be a chatroom or any other resource on the Internet.

column2: $x_1$ is a pillow fight in which $x_2$ fights $x_3$ over issue $x_4$, using pillows/cushions $x_5$.
$x_1$ engages in a pillow fight with $x_2$ over issue $x_3$, using pillows/cushions $x_4$.
$m_1$=$k_2$ is a mattress with cushion $k_1$.
$x_1$ varies in what it is in relation $x_2$ to, transiting to a relation with $x_3$ from one with $x_4$
$x_1$ makes $x_2$ and $x_3$ be related by binary relation $x_4$.
$x_1$ is a relation space formed from elements/nodes in set $x_2$ and relationship $x_3$ which connects them.
column3: $x_1$ is a space/directed graph/set of ordered n-tuples which is formed from the endowment of of a space/set (of possible nodes) $x_2$ with the relationship $x_3$ which is n-ary.  Suppose that $x_2$ is binary; let y and z be elements in $x_2$ and denote $x_3$ by "R" so that "a R b" means that R relates 'a' to 'b' in that order (not necessarily the reverse); then: if y R z, then (y,z) is an element in $x_1$. In other words, $x_1$ is the set of exactly all ordered edges between members of $x_2$ (which are nodes/endpoints of members of $x_1$), which are formed iff R relates those members in the order indicated by the direction of the edge (source then destination; first term, then second term) when R is binary. Greater arity is possible (in which case ordered n-tuples become useful and edges scale up dimensionally). $x_1$ is the set of all ordered relationships in $x_2$ formed by $x_3$. One valjvo of this word is an experimental gismu: {grafu}.

column2: In the sequence $x_1$, each nonfinal member is related to the next member by the relation $x_2$.
$c_1$ lacks oxygen $k_1$; $c_1$ is anaerobic.
$s_3$ [recipient] is insufficiently/deficiently supplied with oxygen from $s_1$ [source], insufficiently by standard $d_3$.
$x_1$ blunts $x_2$
$x_{1}$ spear/lance/assegai made of $x_{2}$.
$x_1$=$xa_1$=$g_1$=$k_1$ is a lance/spear/javelin/pointed-rod weapon for use against $x_2$=$xa_2$ by $x_3$=$xa_3$ of material $x_4$=$g_2$.
column3: {kinli} {grana} {xarci}; this lujvo structure is from {noralujv}. The author of this definition is uncertain that {jesxa'i} would not be a better lujvo for the purpose.

column2: $x_1$ is a spine or thorn protruding from $x_2$
$x_1$ is a sting/stinger of $x_2$
$d_1$ is a movie theater / cinema (building) showing movies/films $s_1$.
$x_1$ is confused about message $x_2$ (text/sedu'u) from sender $x_3$
$x_1$ is an (Internet) meme about $x_2$ using format $x_3$.
column3: Refers to Internet memes about a topic (se kibmeme) using a repeating format, e.g. "Drake Hotline approves" (te kibmeme). See also {sibvidru}.

column2: $x_1$ is a web browser.
$x_1$ and $x_2$ are such that the former is in relation $x_3$ with a greater number than that which the latter is in that relation with.

$x_1$ is in relation $x_4$ with $x_2$ to the $x_3$th degree; $x_1$ is $x_3$ nodes before $x_2$ in the sequence such that every element thereof and the next element are linked by the relation $x_4$; $x_1$ is [ that which is in relation $x_4$ with ] (repeat $x_3$ times the part between brackets) $x_2$
column3: X ki'inmoi Y li ci lo ka ce'u ce'u pendo = X is a friend of a friend of a friend of Y (so a "third degree friend"). X ki'inmoi Y li vo lo ka ce'u ce'u mamta = X is the mother of the mother of the mother of the mother of Y; X is [the mother of]×4 Y.

column2: $x_1$ is a sequence in which each adjacent pair of elements is related by $x_2$ (binary predicate; applied in the order of the sequence).
column3: For example, "lo {serlaximorfa} {ce'o} lo {oxtopoda} ce'o lo {finpe} ce'o lo {alga} cu ki'irsi lo ka ce'u ce'u {citka}" expresses "sharks eat octopuses, and octopuses eat fish, and fish eat algae."

column2: $x_1$ is a cymbal/gong of radius $x_2$, made of material $x_3$
$x_1$ does $x_2$ (ka/nu) to show that they satisfy binary property $x_3$ (ka) with/to audience $x_4$.
column3: The first {ce'u} in both $x_2$ and $x_3$ is the actor ($x_1$). The second {ce'u} in both $x_2$ and $x_3$ is the audience ($x_4$).

column2: Quezon City, Metro Manila, Philippines
Quixote/Quijote
attitudinal question: metalinguistic confusion caused by too many experimental cmavo
Converts following selbri, cmevla, or zoi-quote into a nonce interjection/attitudinal.
non-question: understanding of something said.
{ki'au} - evidential: I reason\n{ki'aunai} - I think impulsively.
column3: Can be used similar to krinu/ki'u in UI form.

column2: vocative: \n{ki'e } - thanks\n{ki'e nai} - no thanks to you.
$x_{1}$ is sharp/keen at locus $x_{2}$.
$x_{1}$ reflects Pakistani/Pashto culture/nationality/language in aspect $x_{2}$.
$x_{1}$ is a street/avenue/lane/drive/cul-de-sac/way/alley/[road] at $x_{2}$ accessing $x_{3}$.
column3: Also corridor; not typically a route between points, but offers access to sites along it.  See also {naxle}, {panka}, {pluta}, {dargu}.

column2: $x_{1}$ weeps/cries tears $x_{2}$ about/for reason $x_{3}$ (event/state).
$x_{1}$ comes/goes to destination $x_{2}$ from origin $x_{3}$ via route $x_{4}$ using means/vehicle $x_{5}$.
column3: Also travels, journeys, moves, leaves to ... from ...; $x_1$ is a traveller; ($x_4$ as a set includes points at least sufficient to constrain the route relevantly).  See also {cadzu}, {bajra}, {marce}, {vofli}, {litru}, {muvdu}, {cpare}, cmavo list {ka'a}, {pluta}, {bevri}, {farlu}, {limna}, {vitke}.

column2: $x_1$ is measured by $x_2$ (number) on scale $x_3$ (si'o, property of $x_1$ with kau).
column3: Also count. To specify the number of objects, {loi} is usually used in x1 of klani. To specify size, fill x3 of klani. See also cmavo list {la'u}, {namcu}.

column2: $x_{1}$ (mass/si'o) is a class/category/subgroup/subset within $x_{2}$ with defining property $x_{3}$ (ka).
column3: Also taxon, type, kind, classification, species, genus, family, order, phylum.  See also cmavo list {le'a}, {cmima}, {jutsi}, {ciste}, {girzu}, {lanzu}, {vrici}.

column2: $x_{1}$ (object/medium) is clear/transparent/without obstacle to in-the-clear $x_{2}$ [transmission].
column3: Also lucid; $x_2$ remains apparent/lucid/clear (figurative use for 'understandable' is discouraged, better expressed as = {filseljmi} or {filsmu}).  (cf. {kandi}, {zunti} - {nalzu'i} is better for 'unhindered')

column2: $x_{1}$ is a quantity of/contains/is made of halogen of type $x_{2}$ [chlorine, fluorine, iodine, etc.].
column3: Also bromine; default chlorine. See also {xukmi}.

column2: $x_{1}$ is a quantity of/contains/is made of clay [moist, clammy dirt] of composition including $x_{2}$.
digit/number: number comma; thousands.
{krinu} modal, 1st place (justified by)             justifiably; because of reason ...
$x_1$ is a binary relationship which is reflexive in space/under conditions/on set $x_2$.
column3: Denote this binary relation $x_1$ between elements y, z (in that order) by "y R z" (in that order); then, for any element 'a' in the set of consideration (possibly $x_2$), a R a. "Reflexive property" = "ka(m)( )kinra". See also: {takni}, {kinfi}.

column2: $x1$ keeps/raises $x2$ [animals] in sty/stall/stale/pen $x3$ for purpose $x4$
$x_1$ is the $x_2$ (number)-th episode in broadcast series $x_3$
$x_1$ is an episode of movie/television series $x_2$
$x_1$=$p_1$=$s_3$=$s_4$ thinks about subject $x_2$=$p_2$=$s_2$ by imagining $x_3$=$s_1$ which is like an imaginary movie about that subject.
$x_1$ is an individual program in radio or television series $x_2$
$x_1$=$s_1$ is a frame from motion picture $x_2$=$k_1$ about $x_3$=$k_2$ [plot/theme/subject/activity]
column3: (skina x3, x4 omitted for lack of usefulness). See also {skina} for some useful lujvo you can tanru-ize this with -- e.g. "selxraci'a skina" -> 'frame of drawn animation', {selci}

column2: $x_1$=$z_1$ watches movie/film/audio-video $x_2$=$z_2$=$s_1$ about subject $x_3$=$s_2$ by filmmaker $x_4$=$s_3$ intended for audience $x_5$=$s_4$ by sensory means $x_6$=$z_3$ under conditions $x_7$=$z_4$
column3: {velskina} is less appropriate because it isn't true that the entire intended audience of a film will watch it, not to mention that it is possible to watch films of which one is not a part of the intended audience. See also {skina}, {zgana}.

column2: $d1$ is $d2$ full kilodays (thousand day unit) in duration (default is 1 kiloday) by standard $d3$
column3: For use with metric dating system.

column2: $g_1$ is $g_2$ kilograms in mass by standard $g_3$.
$x_1$ is measured in $x_2$ (default 1) kilobits ($10^3$ bits)
$se1$ is (close to) a thousand of eight indivisible, most basic computer subunits of computer $se2$; se1 is a kilobyte
column3: In binary a kilobyte is actually 1024 bytes, but we can round off for brevity, and to parallel the metric units.

column2: $n1$ is $n2$ millennia (1000 years) in duration (default is 1 millennium) by standard $n3$.
column3: Millennium not limited to decimal equivalent of "1000".

column2: $x_1$ is $x_2$ (li; default: 1) kiloparsecs by standard $x_3$.
$x_1$ is $x_2$ kilometres long in direction $x_3$ by standard $x_4$.
$d_1$ is Thanksgiving by standard $d_3$
column3: From la berenstein cribe 2020/11/17 See also {ckire}, {djedi}

column2: $x_1$ thanks/gives thanks to $x_2$ for $x_3$ (property) via medium $x_4$
$r_1$ is measured in pakistani rupee (₨; PKR) as $r_2$ (quantity), in the Algerian monetary system $r_3$.
$k_1$=$b_1$ is the Pakistani Urdu language used by $b_2$ to communicate $b_3$ (si'o/du'u, not quote)
$k_1$=$g_1$=$b_1$ is the Pakistani English language used by $b_2$ to express/communicate $b_3$ (si'o/du'u, not quote).
$k_1$=$g_1$ is Pakistan.
column3: Cf. {kisto}, {gugde}, {gugdepuku}.  The 'national' language of Pakistan is {xurbau}.

column2: $x_1$ is pottery made by $x_2$ of clay $x_3$.
$b_1$ is a clay-based building brick of composition $k_2$,  surfaces/sides $s_4$.
$b_1$ is a clay bottle/jar/urn/flask/closable container made of clay for $b2_2$ with lid $b_4$.
$x_1$ is a potter who makes $x_2$ out of clay $x_3$.
$c_1$ calls/summons $c_3$=$k_1$ to location $k_2$ in manner/form $c_4$.
$ca1$ is pager for calling $ca2$=$cp3$ controlled/[triggered] by $ca3$=$cp1$
$x_1$ is a flux/traffic of pedestrians/vehicles $x_2$ going to $x_3$ from $x_4$
$x_1$ brings $x_2$ to $x_3$
$x_1$ leads/guides $x_2$ to $x_3$ from $x_4$ via route $x_5$
$j_1$=$k_1$ follows $j_2$ to destination $k_2$ from origin $k_3$ via route $k_4$ by means $k_5$.
$x_1$ goes and returns to $x_2$ from $x_3$ via $x_4$ by using $x_5$.
column3: It means '$x_1$ goes to $x_2$ from $x_3$, and then $x_1$ goes to $x_3$ from $x_2$'.

column2: $z_1$, more than $z_2$, goes to $k_2$ from $k_3$ via $k_4$ by means of $k_5$.
